description.raw:
The task was given by the Ministry of Health; To assess if the proof of concept that Babyl had to implement for 12 Months succeeded of not. The team is composed by MOH, MINICT, RDB , RBC abd RSSB.

**Meeting 1:** The meeting held at MOH on 07th May 2019, lead by State Minister MoH, and the purpose was to brief the team on the Assignment.

**Meeting 2(On 10th May 2019):** Second meeting the team stated the analysis of MOU between GoR and Babyl; We identified 6 Responsibilities that Babyl was supposed to Honor in the given 12 months. The team decided to meet Babyl Authorities to hear how they implemented the agreed activities.

**Meeting 3( on 13th May 2019):** Site Visit to Babyl and Presentation on how Babyl works; The team requested some questions to understand if they implemented what was agreed. The time were a constraint and Next meeting will be scheduled and communicated.

**Next Meeting:** Planned on 16th May 2019, The target is for the team to put together the findings and produce a draft report

The draft report was done as planned, Missing information will be completed after the second meeting with Babyl' Officials on **Wednesday 22nd May at 2 pm in Ministry of Health level 1 Boardroom.**

description.raw:
To work with MoH, MINICT, RBC to develop a detailed plan of the approved Projects to be implemented 2019/2020.

**Meeting 1( on 25/04/2019):** The discussion was to link the priority projects defined in Smart Rwanda Master Plan and the ones recommended by Healthcare digital transformation Strategy. Output of the Meeting  was the list of priority projects to be implemented next year:

1.  Development of interoperability Standards + Security and governance framework
2.  Health Information Exchange
3.  Telemedicine project
4.  Rwanda Health Cloud
5.  National Centralized Vendor Neutral PACS

**Meeting 2 (08/05/2019):** Meeting with PS-MoH, PS-MINICT , teams of MoH, RBC and RISA to approve the priority projects; the meeting approved the projects and requested the teams  to work on detailed plan to help in proving the allocated budget.

**Next meeting :** Planned on 16th May  2019 at MoH targeted outcome is the detailed budget plan for proposed projects.

**Meeting 3:** The meeting was done as planned on 16th May 2019 at MOH, the decision was to request Gaju( Head of E-Health at MOH) to do a draft in collaboration with Haider and team will meet again to review and finalize.

description.raw:
_Community Health Workers are at the front line of the health sector system providing promotional, prevention and curative services at community level. This entails the use of several programmatic tools and production of different reports. This requires a lot of Monitoring &Evaluation tools which are expensive to the sector. In addition, the continuous capacity building of CHWs remains a challenge to the sector given their big number (around 60,000) and turnover rate. In order to respond to the above mentioned challenges and in line with the national SMART Rwanda Master Plan, the Ministry of health opted for a digital solution that can be used during service delivery, reporting and continuous training._

_The meeting was convened to discuss the application and tool to be used for Community Health Workers._

Meeting 1: Resolutions :

_**R.1.1** The meeting recommended to use tablets_

_**R.1.2.** MARA team to explore manufacturing tablets and give feedback to MoH_

_**R.1.3** MoH to share tablets technical specifications with MARA team_

_**R.1.4.** Ingobyi to hold a bit on the procurement of other tablets_

_**R.2.1.** Ingobyi team to identify the budget allocated to registers and communicate to MoH_

_**R.3.1.** Ingobyi and Jeev teams to meet and align on the e-learning part of the application_

_**R.4.1** Jeev team to work with Local technical firms_

_**R.5.1.** MoH and RISA teams to share requirements and guidelines on data hosting and accessibility for Jeev compliance_

**Next Activity: MARA Company** to confirm to MOH if they are ready to produce tablets by 16/05/2019.

Community Health Workers are at the front line of the health sector system providing promotional, prevention and curative services at community level. This entails the use of several programmatic tools and production of different reports. This requires a lot of Monitoring &Evaluation tools which are expensive to the sector. In addition, the continuous capacity building of CHWs remains a challenge to the sector given their big number (around 60,000) and turnover rate. In order to respond to the above mentioned challenges and in line with the national SMART Rwanda Master Plan, the Ministry of health opted for a digital solution that can be used during service delivery, reporting and continuous training.

The meeting was convened to discuss the application and tool to be used for Community Health Workers.

Meeting 1: Resolutions :

R.1.1 The meeting recommended to use tablets

R.1.2. MARA team to explore manufacturing tablets and give feedback to MoH

R.1.3 MoH to share tablets technical specifications with MARA team

R.1.4. Ingobyi to hold a bit on the procurement of other tablets

R.2.1. Ingobyi team to identify the budget allocated to registers and communicate to MoH

R.3.1. Ingobyi and Jeev teams to meet and align on the e-learning part of the application

R.4.1 Jeev team to work with Local technical firms

R.5.1. MoH and RISA teams to share requirements and guidelines on data hosting and accessibility for Jeev compliance

Next Activity: MARA Company to confirm to MOH if they are ready to produce tablets by 16/05/2019.

description.raw:
The project targets to Implement HIE and  Develop linkage Solution for generating EMR data directly to HMIS.

Next event:  Kick off Meeting on 15/05/2019

Kick off meeting was done: RBC and SEVICS company agreed on how the consultancy will be done. Document and situation analysis will start by 16th/05/2019. RISA to send the requirements for HIE. Next stage will be presentation of inception report in two weeks time.

On 11/07/2019: The current status of the project is on the development of interconnection between different APIs. The API they are using now are from NIDA, LAB system and OpenMRS. In August it is planned the demo  and testing on integration.

description.raw:
#### OpenIMIS is the first open source software that manages social (health) protection schemes. It links beneficiary, provider and payer data. It is a powerful tool to strengthen strategic purchasing and digital processing of health system data.

Meeting 1: Friday 17th May 2019 at RSSB 9 am; Meet the OpenIMIS team in the week of 21st to 24th May 2019

Resolutions of the meeting held on 17th May 2019:

1.  RSSB to draft a technical requirement document that describes what will be the scope of  the system they are acquiringfor claims management(OpenIMIS). Document to be shared with RISA for Review
2.  The meeting advised that,  as RSSB has chosen this solution OpenIMIS it should not be developed to be abandoned in 2 years as suggested but to be part of the whole computerization process of RSSB. To ignore the idea of creating it as temporary solution.
3.  The meeting recommended that during the negotiation with the company, The following points should be described among others: - How and where the customization  will be done; -Knowledge transfer plan, Ownership, Hosting, After service support and Maintenance, System integration with other existing systems; sustainability in terms of cost after the development and Upgrade plan as this is an opensource system.
4.  To check the profile of the company that is going to customize the solution and its valid similar work references.

Resolutions of the meeting held on 17th May 2019:

  1. RSSB to draft a technical requirement document that describes what will be the scope of  the system they are acquiringfor claims management(OpenIMIS). Document to be shared with RISA for Review
  2. The meeting advised that,  as RSSB has chosen this solution OpenIMIS it should not be developed to be abandoned in 2 years as suggested but to be part of the whole computerization process of RSSB. To ignore the idea of creating it as temporary solution.

  4. To check the profile of the company that is going to customize the solution and its valid similar work references.

View this email in your browser 

Cliquez ici pour la version française 
2019 TRANSFORM AFRICA SUMMIT

Face the Gorillas:

Face the Gorillas is a fast paced, high stakes pitching session anchored by Yariv Cohen. The session invites entrepreneurs from across Africa who will explain their businesses and pitch for investment. based on what they hear, the "Gorillas" or Investors will offer to invest in the businesses. This is one of the most popular sessions at the Transform Africa Summit.
Click HERE to watch the Face the Gorillas session
 

Policy Harmonization as a tool for bridging the digital gap in Africa:
Africa has entered the digital revolution, the main engine for bridging the digital gap on the continent. Aware of the need to make communication more affordable throughout the continent, international organizations, including the Smart Africa Alliance, are proposing to adopt policy harmonization framework across African countries to achieve economies of scale leading to the reduction of prices and as a result, promote digital inclusion.
Click HERE to watch the panel on Policy Harmonization

From: NZEYIMANA Cleophas  
Sent: Thursday, July 11, 2019 6:50 PM
To: 'lucie uwizeye' 
Cc: 'typo3support' ; 'lucie uwizeye' ; 'MUKARUKUNDO Josette' ; 'KAMBANDA Jeanine' 
Subject: RE: Gusaba support

 

Dear Lucie,

Ndabashimiye ku bufasha mwaduhaye.
Mwareba hari amafoto akizamuka ubona afatanye, hakaba n’abamuka akarenga cadre umutwe ntugaragare wose.
Mwareba kandi hari amafoto adafunguka ya ba Hon. Ahishakiye Mediatrice, Bakundufite Christine na Basigayabo Marcelline, ntagaragara.
TUbashimiye ubufatanye

Cleophas

 

 

From: lucie uwizeye [mailto:lucie.uwizeye@risa.gov.rw] 
Sent: Thursday, July 11, 2019 3:47 PM
To: NZEYIMANA Cleophas
Cc: typo3support; lucie uwizeye; MUKARUKUNDO Josette; KAMBANDA Jeanine
Subject: Re: Gusaba support

 

Dear Cleophas,

 

Ubusabe bwanyu bwakiriwe neza. Turabamenyeshako ikibazo mwari mufite k'urubuga “frame” y’amafoto y’Abadepite agenda asimburana agaragara nabi kandi umwimerere w’amafoto ugaragaza ko ari meza cyakosowe, mwongere musure urubuga kugira murebeko ikibazo cyavuyemo.

 

Murakoze

 

  _____  

From: "NZEYIMANA Cleophas" <  cleophas.nzeyimana@parliament.gov.rw>
To: "typo3support" <  typo3support@risa.gov.rw>
Cc: "lucie uwizeye" <  lucie.uwizeye@risa.rw>, "MUKARUKUNDO Josette" <  josette.mukarukundo@parliament.gov.rw>, "KAMBANDA Jeanine" <  Jeanine.kambanda@parliament.gov.rw>
Sent: Wednesday, July 3, 2019 7:51:43 AM
Subject: Gusaba support

 

Dear team,

Twabasabaga ko mwareba kuri website yacu, mukongera “frame” y’amafoto y’Abadepite agenda asimburana (slidind) kuko agaragara nabi kandi umwimerere w’amafoto ugaragaza ko ari meza.
Tubashimiye ubufatanye

 

=== ====== === =====

Cléophas NZEYIMANA

Rwanda Parliament

Ag.Director of Outreach & Documentation Unit

Telephone : (250)788471000

Office telephone : 252594714

Email:cleophas.nzeyimana@parliament.gov.rw

              cleociceronis@gmail.com

description.raw:
From: "Antoine Sebera"  
To: "didas turatsinze" , "Marcellin" , "Maryse Gwiza"  
Cc: "Elisabeth Ujeneza" , "Ngoga" , "Pierre"  
Sent: Monday, July 15, 2019 10:10:07 PM 
Subject: RE: Business Intelligence Use Case 



Dear Didas, 



Thank you for the follow-up. Next week is still ok! Please keep this in your radar as a potential good project to make a difference at grassroots level with a good dashboard/Big Data solution. 



Thanks, 






From: Didas Turatsinze  
Sent: Monday, July 15, 2019 3:16 PM 
To: 'Antoine Sebera' ; marcellin.nyirishyaka@risa.gov.rw; 'Maryse Gwiza'  
Cc: 'Elisabeth Ujeneza' ; 'Ngoga Said'  
Subject: RE: Business Intelligence Use Case 




Dear sir, 

Trusting this mail finds you well, I received your e-mail about that good manual data capture initiative in Ngoma District but when talked to E/S district said that, they can receive us next week that, they are busy this week with imihigo evaluators. They need time to orient us in health centers, schools and cells. 

Rgds Didas 




From: Antoine Sebera [ [ mailto:antoine.sebera@risa.gov.rw | mailto:antoine.sebera@risa.gov.rw ] ] 
Sent: Monday, July 15, 2019 8:07 AM 
To: [ mailto:marcellin.nyirishyaka@risa.gov.rw | marcellin.nyirishyaka@risa.gov.rw ] ; 'Didas Turatsinze' < [ mailto:didas.turatsinze@risa.gov.rw | didas.turatsinze@risa.gov.rw ] >; 'Maryse Gwiza' < [ mailto:maryse.gwiza@risa.gov.rw | maryse.gwiza@risa.gov.rw ] > 
Cc: 'Elisabeth Ujeneza' < [ mailto:elisabeth.ujeneza@risa.gov.rw | elisabeth.ujeneza@risa.gov.rw ] >; 'Ngoga Said' < [ mailto:saidngoga.rutabayiro@risa.gov.rw | saidngoga.rutabayiro@risa.gov.rw ] > 
Subject: Business Intelligence Use Case 




Dears, 



What can RISA do to help such good initiatives: [ https://www.newtimes.co.rw/news/sakes-unique-model-designed-improve-education-quality | https://www.newtimes.co.rw/news/sakes-unique-model-designed-improve-education-quality ] 






They are still using papers. How can we enable them with IT? Can we have a quick solution (open source for example) 



Call for Action : 



- Didas and Maryse to organize an initial site visit this week to see how we can collaborate with them. You can associate the intern from AIMS 

- Propose a short-term and medium term plan 



Any suggestion is welcome. 



Thanks,
description.html:
From: "Antoine Sebera"
To: "didas turatsinze" , "Marcellin" , "Maryse Gwiza"
Cc: "Elisabeth Ujeneza" , "Ngoga" , "Pierre"
Sent: Monday, July 15, 2019 10:10:07 PM
Subject: RE: Business Intelligence Use Case

Dear Didas,

Thank you for the follow-up. Next week is still ok! Please keep this in your radar as a potential good project to make a difference at grassroots level with a good dashboard/Big Data solution.

Thanks,

From: Didas Turatsinze
Sent: Monday, July 15, 2019 3:16 PM
To: 'Antoine Sebera' ; marcellin.nyirishyaka@risa.gov.rw; 'Maryse Gwiza'
Cc: 'Elisabeth Ujeneza' ; 'Ngoga Said'
Subject: RE: Business Intelligence Use Case

Dear sir,

Trusting this mail finds you well, I received your e-mail about that good manual data capture initiative in Ngoma District but when talked to E/S district said that, they can receive us next week that, they are busy this week with imihigo evaluators. They need time to orient us in health centers, schools and cells.

Rgds Didas

From: Antoine Sebera [ [ mailto:antoine.sebera@risa.gov.rw | mailto:antoine.sebera@risa.gov.rw ] ]
Sent: Monday, July 15, 2019 8:07 AM
To: [ mailto:marcellin.nyirishyaka@risa.gov.rw | marcellin.nyirishyaka@risa.gov.rw ] ; 'Didas Turatsinze' < [ mailto:didas.turatsinze@risa.gov.rw | didas.turatsinze@risa.gov.rw ] >; 'Maryse Gwiza' < [ mailto:maryse.gwiza@risa.gov.rw | maryse.gwiza@risa.gov.rw ] >
Cc: 'Elisabeth Ujeneza' < [ mailto:elisabeth.ujeneza@risa.gov.rw | elisabeth.ujeneza@risa.gov.rw ] >; 'Ngoga Said' < [ mailto:saidngoga.rutabayiro@risa.gov.rw | saidngoga.rutabayiro@risa.gov.rw ] >
Subject: Business Intelligence Use Case

Dears,

What can RISA do to help such good initiatives: [ https://www.newtimes.co.rw/news/sakes-unique-model-designed-improve-education-quality | https://www.newtimes.co.rw/news/sakes-unique-model-designed-improve-education-quality ]

They are still using papers. How can we enable them with IT? Can we have a quick solution (open source for example)

Call for Action :

  • Didas and Maryse to organize an initial site visit this week to see how we can collaborate with them. You can associate the intern from AIMS

  • Propose a short-term and medium term plan

Any suggestion is welcome.

Thanks,

From: lucie uwizeye  
Sent: Tuesday, July 16, 2019 9:36 AM
To: Typo3 Support 
Subject: Fwd: Looking for urgent assistance

 

 

FYI

  _____  

From: "Emmanuel B. HARERIMANA" <  eharerimana@environment.gov.rw>
To: "lucie uwizeye" <  lucie.uwizeye@risa.rw>
Cc: "tuyisenge solange" <  solange.tuyisenge@aos.rw>, "MoE ICT" <  ICT@environment.gov.rw>
Sent: Monday, July 15, 2019 4:49:42 PM
Subject: FW: Looking for urgent assistance

 

Dear Lucie,

 

I forward to you  the communication I had with Datacenter, for your support.

Normally our website run the version 8.7 of typo3. And around 9:00am i managed to enter the backend, and this afetrnonn I tried to browse in vain the website and no access to backend. Our index page is in /public_html/index.php.

 

Could you please assist?

 

Regards 

 

 

From: Solange Tuyisenge [mailto:solange.tuyisenge@aos.rw] 
Sent: Monday, 15 July, 2019 03:50 PM
To: Emmanuel B. HARERIMANA  >
Cc: idc  >; MoE ICT  >
Subject: Re: Looking for urgent assistance

 

Hi Emmanuel,

 

The website is running on 7.1 we have not made any change but we can see some funny files under your public_html

do you recognine 0.htm, s.htm,z.html....?

 

 

Regards,

 

Solange

 

  _____  

From: "Emmanuel B. HARERIMANA" <  eharerimana@environment.gov.rw>
To: "idc" <  idc@aos.rw>
Cc: "MoE ICT" <  ICT@environment.gov.rw>, "Solange Tuyisenge" <  solange.tuyisenge@aos.rw>
Sent: Monday, July 15, 2019 3:22:08 PM
Subject: Looking for urgent assistance

 

Dear Datacenter Team,

 

It seems that our website (www.environment.gov.rw  ) is OFF. When trying to browse no content  is getting and try to access the back end the following image is displayed.

 

 



Is there any change made on your side? 

We appreciate your assistance and support.

 

Regards 

 


 

 




HARERIMANA Emmanuel B.

Network and System Application Administrator

Ministry of Environment(MoE)

  Tel:(+250) 788313458

Email: eharerimana@environment.gov.rw

description.html:
—————————————
Said Rutabayiro Ngoga, PhD
Division Manager Technology Innovation
Rwanda Information Society Authority (RISA)
saidngoga.rutabayiro@risa.gov.rw
said.rutabayiro.ngoga@gmail.com
+250 783 111 906

On Jul 15, 2019, at 17:18, Fischer, Torsten Franz GIZ RW wrote:

Dear all,

I hope you are well.

There was now a quick exchange between Jovani and myself to address the question of ownership of the platform and the related data.

GIZ DSSD is leading this project on the GIZ side and we made sure that whatever is developed will be released under an open source license, therefor we are not limited in terms of IP or the like.

However, Jovani and I agreed to resolve any open question during the upon coming stake holder meeting, which has been tentatively set on July 30th from 10 am.
A formal invitation will follow as soon as we have confirmation from all parties involved.

We hope that this will allow us to move forward with the development and data collection.
If there are any further concerns, kindly reach out to either Jovani or myself.

Thank you and kind regards,

Torsten Fischer

From: Jovani Ntabgoba >
Sent: Monday, July 15, 2019 12:44 PM
To: Tesi Rusagara >; Philip Gasatura >; saidngoga rutabayiro >
Cc: Fischer, Torsten Franz GIZ RW >; Shoichi Iwata >; immaculatemutesi.rw >; Furukawa Masayuki >; Antoine Sebera >; Alex Ntale >
Subject: Rwanda ICT Ecosystem Information Data Collection and Publication

Dear Tesi, Philip and Saidi,

I hope you are doing well.

At JICA-ICT Innovation Ecosystem Strengthening Project together with GiZ_Rwanda, we are working on a project to collect basic information of Rwandan ICT Ecosystem Players and Publish the information on a web platform before TICAD7 28th August.

JICA-ICT is to do the basic information collection and GiZ is to build a platform on to which the information will be published. The question still remained on which institution would be the custodian of the platform, since JICA&GiZ don't qualify, may be ICT Chamber, DBI, KIC or RISA would have interest in being the custodian.

The target is to collect basic information of between 300 to 500 Rwandan ICT Companies/Startups.

The platform can be used by Investors, Researchers, Entrepreneurs in need of getting basic contacts or categories of the Rwandan ICT Sector players.
Specifically, we would like to showcase the platform during TICAD7 (28th to 31st August 2019) as means of marketing Rwandan ICT Sector to Japanese investors/entrepreneurs.

However, in the stakeholder meeting of last Friday, we learnt that KIC or RISA is doing a similar project.
To avoid duplication, if KIC or RISA is doing a similar information collection exercise, JICA-ICT Project wishes to get your feedback on whether to continue with the information collection or to stop it and wait for KIC or RISA's information collection.

Please find attached a template of the basic information that we intended to collect.
Thank you,

Regards,

Jovani Ntabgoba
Investment Advisor,
ICT Innovation Ecosystem
Strengthening Project
2nd Floor,Telecom House, BP 5121 Kacyiru, Kigali, Rwanda
Tel: +250 7887 87497 | Skype: jovani .ntabgoba
Deutsche Gesellschaft fuer Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) GmbH;
Sitz der Gesellschaft Bonn und Eschborn/Registered offices Bonn and Eschborn, Germany;
Registergericht/Registered at Amtsgericht Bonn, Germany; Eintragungs-Nr./Registration no. HRB 18384 und/and Amtsgericht Frankfurt am Main, Germany; Eintragungs-Nr./Registration no. HRB 12394;
USt-IdNr./VAT ID no. DE 113891176;
Vorsitzender des Aufsichtsrats/Chairman of the Supervisory Board: Martin Jaeger, Staatssekretaer/State Secretary;
Vorstand/Management Board: Tanja Goenner (Vorstandssprecherin/Chair of the Management Board), Dr. Christoph Beier (Stellv. Vorstandssprecher/Vice-Chair of the Management Board)

On Jul 16, 2019, at 08:30, wrote:

Dear Emmanuel,
Below is a request for training from Didas,
Please see what is popssible from Skills office in RDB or GIZ.
If it is possible we can see if there is an opportunity for may be 2 other staff members.
Thanks.
Innocent
  <>
From: Didas Turatsinze [mailto:didas.turatsinze@risa.gov.rw ]
Sent: Kuwa mbere, 2019 Nyakanga 08 09:15
To: innocent.muhizi@risa.gov.rw
Subject: Big data and Analytics training in india

Good morning sir, trusting this mail finds you well.
Am writing this e-mail to inform your office that I have been invited to a Four days training on platforms /tools and analytics of Big data in india- bangarole by cloudera Apache Hodoop Administration scheduled on 12- 15 August 2019. Since we are hoping to establish or have big data industry in near future , this would be much better for my daily work responsibilities and can even assist me On GCC data Analytics since am following its implementation. I request for your facilitation as an institution since I can’t afford to sponsor myself. Attached is the invitation letter and invoice from cloudera Apache Hodoop Administration.
Looking forward to receiving your good intellectual decisions or considerations.

Turatsinze Didas
M: 0788639421 E: didas.turatsinze@risa.gov.rw I www.risa.rw
Msc.Data.com and S/W Engineering.
Big Data and Analytics development specialist
@RISA.Gov.rw
Telecom House 8KG Ave, kacyiru, Kigali

—————————————
Said Rutabayiro Ngoga, PhD
Division Manager Technology Innovation
Rwanda Information Society Authority (RISA)
saidngoga.rutabayiro@risa.gov.rw
said.rutabayiro.ngoga@gmail.com
+250 783 111 906



> Begin forwarded message:
> 
> From: Abeer Khedr 
> Subject: Rwanda Participation in the AAL Initiative
> Date: July 9, 2019 at 16:34:25 GMT+2
> To: "saidngoga.rutabayiro@risa.gov.rw" , "belyse.umutoni@risa.gov.rw" 
> Cc: Tarek Salah Kamel 
> 
> Dear Dr. Said Ngoga & Ms. Belyse Umutoni,
> First of all, it is our honor to have Republic of Rwanda as a participant in the African App Launchpad (AAL) initiative and it is our pleasure to cooperate with you as a focal point for the focal partner “Rwanda Information Society Authority (RISA)”.
> I need you please to send a list of nominees (5 specific fields in English: Name, Gender, National ID, Birth date, and Selected Learning Track for the nominated learner) according to the initiative eligibility criteria . Then, you need to direct the nominated learners to register on the initiative registration form  which is already opened for your esteemed country.
> Our AAL team will validate the registration data against the nominated list and will revert back to you as a contact person to the focal partner organization; to confirm on the final approved registered learners. Once the approval is received, all learners will be enrolled in the chosen tracks.
> Please also provide us with a high resolution transparent logo for your organization; to be uploaded on the initiative website.
> As we have a target to reach at least a number of 100 applicants from each African country participating with Egypt in the AAL Initiative, kindly find the hereunder 2 links to the initiative Facebook page, as samples for promoting the initiative locally within your country:
> -          https://www.facebook.com/AALauchPad/posts/2268556340134377 
> -          https://www.facebook.com/AALauchPad/posts/2272055119784499 
>  
> Also find below the link to all flyers and marketing materials that can be used for marketing internally.
> https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1hwI9TFfI0aQgHVJoK2iy9BvUT9pu9D4Q 
> For more details about the initiative and its eligibility criteria, please navigate the initiative website: www.AfricanAppLaunchpad.eg 
> For any further information, please contact me directly.
> Regards
>  
> Abeer Khedr, MBA
> Program Management Office Manager
> Software Engineering Competence Center "SECC"
> Information Technology Industry Development Agency "ITIDA"
>  
> Smart Village, Building (B121)
> Cairo-Alexandria Desert Road
> Giza, Egypt 12577
> 
> T +202 3534 5220/5208

Said Rutabayiro Ngoga, PhD

saidngoga.rutabayiro@risa.gov.rw

Begin forwarded message:

From: Abeer Khedr
Subject: Rwanda Participation in the AAL Initiative
Date: July 9, 2019 at 16:34:25 GMT+2
To: "saidngoga.rutabayiro@risa.gov.rw" , "belyse.umutoni@risa.gov.rw"
Cc: Tarek Salah Kamel

Dear Dr. Said Ngoga & Ms. Belyse Umutoni,
First of all, it is our honor to have Republic of Rwanda as a participant in the African App Launchpad (AAL) initiative and it is our pleasure to cooperate with you as a focal point for the focal partner “Rwanda Information Society Authority (RISA)”.
I need you please to send a list of nominees (5 specific fields in English: Name, Gender, National ID, Birth date, and Selected Learning Track for the nominated learner) according to the initiative eligibility criteria . Then, you need to direct the nominated learners to register on the initiative registration form which is already opened for your esteemed country.
Our AAL team will validate the registration data against the nominated list and will revert back to you as a contact person to the focal partner organization; to confirm on the final approved registered learners. Once the approval is received, all learners will be enrolled in the chosen tracks.
Please also provide us with a high resolution transparent logo for your organization; to be uploaded on the initiative website.
As we have a target to reach at least a number of 100 applicants from each African country participating with Egypt in the AAL Initiative, kindly find the hereunder 2 links to the initiative Facebook page, as samples for promoting the initiative locally within your country:

  •      https://www.facebook.com/AALauchPad/posts/2268556340134377 

  •      https://www.facebook.com/AALauchPad/posts/2272055119784499

Also find below the link to all flyers and marketing materials that can be used for marketing internally.
https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1hwI9TFfI0aQgHVJoK2iy9BvUT9pu9D4Q
For more details about the initiative and its eligibility criteria, please navigate the initiative website: www.AfricanAppLaunchpad.eg
For any further information, please contact me directly.
Regards

Abeer Khedr, MBA
Program Management Office Manager
Software Engineering Competence Center "SECC"
Information Technology Industry Development Agency "ITIDA"

Smart Village, Building (B121)
Cairo-Alexandria Desert Road
Giza, Egypt 12577

T +202 3534 5220/5208
F +202 3539 2134
akhedr@itida.gov.eg
www.secc.org.eg

Subject: Visit to Rwanda Coding Academy
 
Dear Technical Team, 
 
In our previous technical meeting, we received amazing report on the good progress RCA has made. We also discussed several shortcomings facing the school that needs our attention. Both PS/MINICT and VC-RP have suggested that a joint team makes a trip to RCA, witnesses the welfare of students and discuss any emerging challenges. This email serves to invite all stakeholders to kindly consider joining us in this very important trip on Tuesday 16th July 2019. The attached list is for the technical team that ought to seek permission from institutional heads and join the visit on Tuesday.
 
Regards, Gordon 
===
Kalema Gordon
Director General, National Digital Transformation
Ministry of ICT & Innovation (MINICT)
Mob:+250785100518 www.minict.gov.rw 
Email:gkalema@minict.gov.rw

From: Ben Rwamucyo >
Sent: Monday, July 15, 2019 11:11 AM
To: mgasana@caa.gov.rw ; kjolly@caa.gov.rw 
Cc: 'Anne Marie Uyisenga'; amunezero@minict.gov.rw ; 'Thierry Mihigo Kalisa'; 'SRN_RISA'; gkalema@minict.gov.rw 
Subject: VAT exemption for Drones
 
 
Dear Marshal, Jolly,
 
I believe this finds you well. I would like to introduce you to this exercise of VAT exemption on drones and drone equipment.
 
As it has been requested by some of the drone operators (Charis) to waive VAT on drones and their equipment. After verifying that this can be one of the enablers for growth in the ICT sector mainly for the drone industry, MINICT and RISA began working towards achieving this goal.
Currently, we are discussing with MINECOFIN to find an efficient method which would exempt VAT on drones for only operators with commercial drone operation license.
Following that approach, we would like to know the licensing procedure and the different types of licenses if any that RCAA issues so that we identify if the above mentioned approach could be employed for this exercise.
 
To introduce the other team members on this exercise; In Cc are Dr. Thierry Kalisa: Head of MPD MINECOFIN, Anne Marie Uyisenga: Tax policy/MPD MINECOFIN, Dr. Said Ngoga: DM Innovation Technology Division/RISA and Gordon Kalema: Director General -  National Digital Transformation/MINICT
 
I have also attached the previous meeting minutes for your reference.
Looking forward to your feedback.
 
With regards,
 

Ben RWAMUCYO
Drones Technologies Development Specialist
ben.rwamucyo@risa.gov.rw 
(+250) 788 647 719
Twitter: @rwamucyoben
 
 


Thomas Wiemann

thomas.wiemann@risa.gov.rw

+250789066168

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: "Michael Nique" >
Date: Wed, Jun 26, 2019 at 5:46 PM +0200
Subject: RE: E-introduction : RISA / GSMA
To: "Rene KABALISA" >, "'Krewer, Jan GIZ RW'" >
Cc: "'Antoine Sebera'" >, "'SRN_RISA'" >, "'Kalema Gordon'" >, "'SYLVIE NSANGA'" >, "'innocent.asiimwe'" >


Dear Rene,
 
Thanks for your quick reply and it is great to learn more about Rwanda adopting this proactive vision towards achieving digital inclusion for everyone.
 
When would be a good time to meet? My schedule is flexible on the Monday 15th and Friday 19th (early morning or mid afternoon). Or we could find a time during the GSMA conference at the Radisson Blu (Tuesday-Thursday). If you are able to participate to the conference, I’d suggest attending the session on the Wednesday morning @9.15am featuring a speaker on disability and technologyhttps://www.mobile360series.com/africa/agenda/sessions/young-gifted-and-african-does-a-culture-of-equality-drive-innovation/ 
Please let me know what would be best.
Kind regards,
 
 
Michael Nique I Mobile for Development Research Director & Assistive Tech Lead I GSMA Mobile 4 Development I  +44 7889 320 189  I mnique@gsma.com  I The Walbrook Building, 25 Walbrook, London, EC4N 8AF I https://www.gsma.com/mobilefordevelopment/assistive-tech/

Subject: RE: E-introduction : RISA / GSMA
 
Dear Jan, thank you for introducing me to Mr. Nique.
 
Dear Nique, thank you for reaching out to us. As you might know Rwanda through the Vision 2020 aimed to become a knowledge-based economy and middle-income country, ICT is considered as a key driver and enabler for social and economic growth. With that we have shown commitment to equality and inclusiveness. However , most of the technology used are not disability friendly.
We have initiated a program to bridge the disability divide, mainstreaming disability issues into the government digitalization agenda by:

Raising awareness of disability needs in the ICT sector and tech industry in general in Rwanda
Support the digitalization of the Disability machineries for efficient services delivery
Develop assistive solutions to contribute to PwDs autonomy and independency
Let’s discuss in details and how we can partner while you are here in July.

Best Regards

 
 
 
 
From: Michael Nique > 
Sent: Tuesday, June 25, 2019 4:28 PM
To: Krewer, Jan GIZ RW >; 'Rene RISA' >
Subject: RE: E-introduction : RISA / GSMA
 
Thanks Jan for the introduction and hi Rene.
 
As Jan mentioned, the GSMA is organising the 360 Africa conference in July that will gather stakeholders from the digital ecosystem to discuss recent and upcoming developments in technology for the African population. Would you be interested to attend these sessions? We will also organise a networking event at the Radisson Blu on the Wednesday 17th evening from 6pm.
 
To give you a bit more background on our work with persons with disabilities, the GSMA recently launched its Assistive Tech programmehttps://www.gsma.com/mobilefordevelopment/assistive-tech/  , based on funding from the Global Disability Innovation (GDI) Hub part of the AT2030 programme funded by DFID. Our aim is first to better understand the level of access and usage of mobile services by persons with disabilities in emerging markets and to understand how mobile can be leveraged as an assistive technology. We published a first landscaping study on the potential of mobile for persons with disabilities late last yearhttps://www.gsma.com/mobilefordevelopment/blog-2/taking-action-to-make-mobile-technologies-and-services-accessible-to-persons-with-disabilities/  . Moving forward, we also intend to create a small innovation fund which will be able to support entrepreneurs in the AT space willing to leverage mobile technologies. Worth mentioning is also the Innovation Fund our partner GDI has recently launched in Nairobi, aiming to support East African entrepreneurs in AT https://innovationchallenge.fund/ 
 
I would be keen to meet with you during that week (15th-19th of July) to share more and better understand your work on digital inclusion for persons with disabilities. Please let me know of your interest.
Kind regards,
 
 
Michael Nique I Mobile for Development Research Director & Assistive Tech Lead I GSMA Mobile 4 Development I  +44 7889 320 189  I mnique@gsma.com  I The Walbrook Building, 25 Walbrook, London, EC4N 8AF I https://www.gsma.com/mobilefordevelopment/assistive-tech/

Subject: Visit to Rwanda Coding Academy

Dear Technical Team,

In our previous technical meeting, we received amazing report on the good progress RCA has made. We also discussed several shortcomings facing the school that needs our attention. Both PS/MINICT and VC-RP have suggested that a joint team makes a trip to RCA, witnesses the welfare of students and discuss any emerging challenges. This email serves to invite all stakeholders to kindly consider joining us in this very important trip on Tuesday 16th July 2019. The attached list is for the technical team that ought to seek permission from institutional heads and join the visit on Tuesday.

Regards, Gordon

Kalema Gordon
Director General, National Digital Transformation
Ministry of ICT & Innovation (MINICT)
Mob:+250785100518 www.minict.gov.rw
Email:gkalema@minict.gov.rw

description.html:
On 17 Jul 2019, 09:01, at 09:01, Juliette NYIRANEZA wrote:

Dear Typo3 Support team ,

Good morning!

We would like to notify you that part of Recent news of
www.mineduc.gov.rw is not visible.
The following message has been displaying since yesterday :
Oops, an error occurred! Code: 2019071613424793466efa

Kindly help restoring it.

Best regards ,
Juliette

.......................................................................................................................................................................

Play your part in the Education Sector Strategic Plan (ESSP): The ESSP
is creating a better education for everyone in Rwanda, which means a
brighter future for all. The ESSP has three main objectives: to
increase ACCESS to education for all; to improve the QUALITY of
education; and to strengthen the RELEVANCE of education for the job
market. Together, we have already achieved a lot. Together, we can go
much further, must faster. Find out more about the ESSP at
www.mineduc.gov.rw. Or follow us on Twitter at @Rwanda_Edu

From: Saga Magali >
Date: Friday, 5 July 2019 at 10:00
To: Thelma Efua Quaye >, >, >, >, >, >, "pingabire@minict.gov.rw " >, Alice HIGIRO >, SRN_RISA >, Josephine Nyiranzeyimana >
Cc: "dg@smartafrica.org " >, Chantal Kayihura >, Didier Nkurikiyimfura >, Henriette Cyuzuzo | Smart Africa >
Subject: Re: INVITATION TO WORKSHOP: FORMULATION OF THE BROADBAND STRATEGY AND SMART CITIES DEVELOPMENT IN AFRICA

Dear Thelma,

We would like to nominate:
Josephine Nyiranzeyimana (RISA) and Fidel Karenzi (MINICT) for the Smart Africa Broadband Strategy Working group
Saidi Ngoga (RISA) and Alice Higiro (MINICT) for the workshop on options and use cases for the development of Smart Cities in Africa

They are all (4) here copied for further information.

Best regards,
Magali

From: Thelma Efua Quaye >
Date: Monday, 1 July 2019 at 16:41
To: >, >, >, >, >, >, "pingabire@minict.gov.rw " >
Cc: "dg@smartafrica.org " >, Chantal Kayihura >, Didier Nkurikiyimfura >, Henriette Cyuzuzo | Smart Africa >
Subject: INVITATION TO WORKSHOP: FORMULATION OF THE BROADBAND STRATEGY AND SMART CITIES DEVELOPMENT IN AFRICA

For the attention of the Honorable Minister,

Following the earlier invitations from Smart Africa Secretariat to nominate a technical representative to the join Smart Africa in formulating the

Broadband Strategy, We are pleased to invite your nominated technical representatives to attend the below ;

· 1st Consultative workshop for the Smart Africa Broadband Strategy Working group

· A workshop on options and use cases for the development of Smart Cities in Africa

Both workshops will happen between the 29th July – 2nd August 2019 in Kigali.

Agenda is as attached and we look forward to your participation in these very exciting workshops.

Warm Regards,

Thelma Efua Quaye
Broadband and Internet Infrastructure development | Smart Africa Secretariat
09th Floor Bloc C, Makuza Peace Plaza | 10 KN4 Avenue | Kigali - Rwanda
Phone number: +250 788-301-451 | +233-266-000-323
website | map | email

Dear Innocent,

I am following on your nominations below to confirm RISA participation of 5 people (including yours) in the AIMS-NEI Executive Education workshop.

Please share with us their contact details including email and cell phone numbers of your colleagues listed below from 2 to 4.

Kind regards,

Charles.

  1.   Antoine SBERA                Government Chief Innovation Officer

  3.   Diana M. GAHIMA          BI Analyst

  4.   Didas TURATSINZE          Big Data Specialist

If there an opportunity for a 5th Position, Then I can also attend.
Thank you.
Innocent

Dear Innocent,

Thank you for your prompt reply.

As I have indicated, this workshop targets c-level executives. Please share with me the names and positions of the 4 people you would like to recommend and we will decide accordingly.

Kind regards,

Charles.

From: Charles Mberi Kimpolo [mailto:Charles.Kimpolo@nexteinstein.org ]
Sent: Kuwa gatatu, 2019 Nyakanga 10 09:56

Cc: meable >; Meable Abaabo >; Antoine Sebera >
Subject: Re: [RISA INVITATION] AIMS-NEI Executive Education - Leveraging the Power of Big Data from 24-26 July 2019

Dear Innocent,

I hope you are keeping well.

This is a follow up on my invitation below as I have not received any feedback from you yet.

Since we only have 2 weeks left before the workshop begins, I will appreciate your feedback on who will be representing RISA. I wish your schedule will permit you to join this c-level executive workshop.

I look forward to hearing from you soon.

Kind regards,

Charles.

Dr. Charles Lebon Mberi Kimpolo, Ph.D.
Director, AIMS Industry Initiative (AIMS I²)

Global Secretariat | The Next Einstein Initiative

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Charles Mberi Kimpolo >
Date: Fri, 7 Jun 2019 at 19:31
Subject: [RISA INVITATION] AIMS-NEI Executive Education - Leveraging the Power of Big Data from 24-26 July 2019
To: >
Cc: meable >, AIMS Industry Initiative >

Dear Innocent,

I trust you are keeping well, noting that it has been a long time. I am still waiting for your feedback regarding your budget availability for the AIMS student internships.

I am writing to invite you to the AIMS-NEI Executive Education - Leveraging the Power of Big Data workshop that AIMS-NEI will be co-organising with Rational AI (a USA based company) from 24-26 July 2019 in Kigali, Rwanda.

Please find attached detailed information about the program, which can be accessed online by clicking here .

The participation in this workshop is by invitation only. Since we have a limited number of seats available, we will encourage each institution to be represented by their leader. I am considering to reserve one seat for RISA. Please confirm and share details of the person who will be representing RISA. I will appreciate receiving this information as soon as possible and kindly let me know if you have any questions.

I look forward to hearing from you soon.

Kind regards,

Charles.

Dr. Charles Lebon Mberi Kimpolo, Ph.D.
Director, AIMS Industry Initiative (AIMS I²)

African Institute for Mathematical Sciences (AIMS)
Global Secretariat | The Next Einstein Initiative
District Gasabo, Secteur Kacyiru,
Cellule Kamatamu, Rue KG590 ST Kigali, Rwanda

Mobile: +221 784460826 (Dakar) | +250 780302682 (Kigali) | +44 7418 429722 (World SIM) | Skype: CharlesKimpolo |

To: "Leonidas" , "Sylvere" , "Thierry" , "Gervais"  
Cc: "Antoine Sebera"  
Sent: Thursday, July 18, 2019 6:16:44 PM 
Subject: assessing institutions level of engagement with DTWMS 

Dear all, 
As discussed this morning with some of you, please team up for an urgently needed assessment of institutions level of engagement in DTWMS and propose categorization as per the level of usage, modules deployed, usage of electronic archiving,purchased licenses,... 
And propose a plan of migration to smart admin or retention of DTWMS per institution accordingly. 

Regards, 
Elisabeth

description.raw:
Get Outlook for Android







From: Charles Bucagu


Sent: Friday, July 19, 11:42


Subject: Fwd: Submission of proposal for a grant: Rwanda Soil Information Service


To: RUTABAYIRO NGOGA SAID, saidngoga.rutabayiro@risa.gov.rw








fyi


-------


Dr. Charles BUCAGU 


Deputy Director General in charge of Agricultural Research and Technology Transfer


Rwanda Agriculture Board (RAB) - Ministry of Agriculture and Animal Resources (MINAGRI)


Mobile: (+250)788305182


E-Mail:bucagucharles@gmail.com






---------- Forwarded message ---------


From: Charles Bucagu 


Date: Tue, Jul 16, 2019 at 9:27 PM


Subject: Re: Submission of proposal for a grant: Rwanda Soil Information Service


To: Christian Witt 


Cc: Jeanne Bridgman , Bernard Vanlauwe (b.vanlauwe@cgiar.org) 






Dear Christian,




I am sharing the revised version of narrative and budget for RwaSIS. We are providing our opinions with regards to a number of issues that you have raised (see track changes). The following are some thoughts on the comments raised in your earlier email:


1- FAIR Data Principles: Regarding the issue of data open access policy, I plan a meeting with RISA, Rwanda Information Society Authority, mandated to oversee Government database storage, management and access. I wish to discuss with them on the opportunity to develop a data open access policy for Rwanda. 


2- Ex-Ante Analysis: The study would be most welcome but I think much of the information we are looking for are already available for Rwanda. My view is that we need simple and straightforward analytical tools to enable identifying priority areas, we already know the priority crops that we should focused on for Rwanda. 


3- Soil conservation: I agree with you on this. Much has been worked on with regards to soil conservation for Rwanda, at least on research side. I do believe  some broader consultation would be much needed to elaborate more on the potential solutions. RAB scientists have extensively worked on soil conservation, highlighting the potential of technologies (solutions) such as bench and progressive terraces, tree and shrubs etc...Other key partners would be the Ministry of Environment. 


4- Project lead: I agree that we need to nominate a project leader. I personally know Dr Alain Ndoli, he is now with IUCN and am not sure he would want to resign and join the project. I have attempted to call him for a discussion but he is currently out of the country. I will make a follow-up on this. However, I tend to favour hiring somebody with experience in AfSIS approach. Simply because this is a 2 years project with high expectation and that will require a project leader who will immediately take the lead and provide a strategic and clear implementation plan without further delays. On the other side, I would welcome an appointment of Rwandan staff (eventually from RAB) serving as assistant project leader to ensure transfer of knowledge and sustainability.


5- I fully support having ISRIC on board and I guess its contribution will be instrumental in equipping national staff with skills and knowledge in digital soil mapping.   




We have proposed changes in track changes for your approval in the narrative and have also made changes in the budget. However, the results framework seem to be protected so it is not possible to add additional rows and insert suggested new activities. May I request any support to enable us accessing files to help capturing those activities. 


Sincerely,


Charles


-------


Dr. Charles BUCAGU 


Deputy Director General in charge of Agricultural Research and Technology Transfer


Rwanda Agriculture Board (RAB) - Ministry of Agriculture and Animal Resources (MINAGRI)


Mobile: (+250)788305182


E-Mail:bucagucharles@gmail.com






On Fri, Jul 5, 2019 at 1:55 PM Christian Witt  wrote:


Dear Charles, 


Apologies for the slight delay in responding to the draft proposal, it has been a very busy month for me but we are still on track with this investment. 


 


In the following, I would like to share some high level feedback and please also not additional comments included in the attached proposal narrative. 


Please revise the proposal and resubmit, if possible, by July 15. 


 


Thank you. 


 


Kind regards,


Christian 


 


Proposal Review – General Comments 


Overall, the proposal is in good shape. I like the overall outline which offers a good structure for implementation. 


 


Key comments: 


FAIR Data Principles. I would like to better understand the current data policy around soils and agronomy in Rwanda. My experience from Ethiopia is that it is worth addressing the issue of data access very early in the process to avoid challenges later. Addressing concerns related to data access late in the process, i.e. retrofitting solutions, will create massive problems in the end. In Ethiopia, the data access policy was so restrictive that not even national research partner could access the data 8 years after the Ethiopian Soil Information Service started its work. It was only know that the Ministry recognized the problem and asked for assistance to developing an appropriate access policy that addressed the concerns of all stakeholders. The Ministry asked the Ethiopian Agricultural Transformation Agency (ATA) to lead the development of a new data access policy for soil data, and they contracted with CABI and the Open Data Institute (ODI) to facilitate the process. It took about six months to develop a draft policy following a highly consultative process (cost was about $200,000). I have heard from national partners in Ethiopia that they were very pleased with the way CABI handled the process. I have attached the draft policy for your reference. Based on this experience, I would like to encourage you to actively address the data access policy and insert a milestone 1.3.1. Data access policy for soil and agronomy data for Rwanda established / revised to ensure success of Rwanda SIS in the Results Framework. In Ethiopia, Please feel free to contact Dr. Martin Parr of CABI (m.parr@cabi.org) to learn about the Ethiopian experience and budget implications should you want to contract with CABI on a similar facilitation. We should be able to increase the project budget slightly to accommodate for this. Ex-ante analysis. We are currently developing a soil acidity project with CIMMYT for Ethiopia and Tanzania to include an ex-ante analysis that would use all existing data to identify priority areas and crops to focus on in the project. This would be the first step before field experiments are conducted. I wonder whether we should include such an ex-ante analysis as an activity under the IO 3 – National Soil Information System to inform activities on IO 1 and 2? CIMMYT could be a thought partner and one could build some light linkages to leverage learning across projects. Partnership development. I could not find much information in the proposal on how you propose to work with partners who you expect to be your customers or clients for data, analytics, and insights. I also did not find any information on how you would consult with partners in understanding their demand for the identified use cases: Fertilizer solutions: As activity 1.1, I would recommend establishing a fertilizer roundtable to ensure that the key players are part of the solution from day 1. This would likely include fertilizer industry representatives (i.e., large suppliers, whole sale, blenders, retail), industry organizations (e.g., fertilizer association, IFDC, AFAP), and other distribution partners (e.g., One Acre Fund) to ensure that there’s demand driven development of products, feedback on technical feasibility both in terms of engineering and product logistics, and user feedback from farmers. For example, we have been working with One Acre Fund to assess opportunities for localized fertilizer solutions tailored to soils and crops while acknowledging limitations to production volume and distribution costs (logistics). An analysis of their agronomic field data has shown that farmers must improve agronomic practices for improved fertilizer to pay off. Also, there’s much short-distance variability in soil properties (often field to field) which makes it impossible to develop a fertilizer product for every field, of course, and therefore requires better rules and recommendations rather than more fertilizer products. This is all very important feedback that needs to be considered right from the beginning. Soil conservation: Again, I would recommend an activity 2.1. to form a roundtable on erosion to make sure that the research to be conducted is informed by key learning of implementing partners in the field and that solutions are developed jointly. Project lead. In our experience, identifying the right project lead up front is key to success. I would like to encourage you to draft the Terms of Reference for this position right away and start looking for a suitable individual. I am sure that you can find suitable candidates in Rwanda but you might need to look a bit more broadly and outside RAB. One of my colleagues suggested Alain Ndoli, currently with the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Kigali office (ndolialain@gmail.com). I don’t know him but wanted to ask whether it was possible to recruit someone from outside RAB to manage the project? I think you would need a full time person to handle the project. I understand that Bernard also suggested looking for a regional recruit who has experience in setting up this kind of project, maybe even someone from Ethiopia who has been part of the EthioSIS project? Please feel free to contact Sam Gameda of CIMMYT, if you wanted to inquire. Sam is Ethiopian and he has been part of the EthioSIS team under the ATA. While Sam would not be the right person, he certainly knows everybody in Ethiopia. I would like to see the Project Lead identified by the fall before we sign the agreement. Role of ISRIC in capacity building. When I spoke with Bernard last week, he indicated that he would like to see ISRIC involved for capacity building on digital soil mapping. I’m open to slightly increasing the budget to accommodate this crucial work stream in order to sustain the effort and strengthen the relationship between RAB and ISRIC. 


 


Proposal Review – Feedback from BMGF Business Partners 


Proposal 


No compliance comments. Christian: Please complete the section titled “Requested Amount” (top section of investment document) 


 


Budget Spreadsheet and Narrative: GCS conducts a compliance-only budget review. You should also review the budget to determine whether the costs in each category are appropriate for the project. 


·        No compliance comments but I did want to flag they’ve budgeted for the purchase of a 4wheel drive vehicle and they’ve also budgeted the lease of vehicles. 


Christian: Please provide the rational for vehicles in the budget narrative


 


Results Framework & Tracker


·        No compliance comments.


 


Thank you. 


We are excited about this project and look forward to hearing from you. 


 


Kind regards,


Christian

Subject: Submission of proposal for a grant: Rwanda Soil Information Service

1- Grant proposal Narrative form

Looking forward to hearing you soon,


Sincerely yours,


Charles

From: Charles Bucagu

Subject: Re: Submission of proposal for a grant: Rwanda Soil Information Service

To: Christian Witt

Cc: Jeanne Bridgman , Bernard Vanlauwe (b.vanlauwe@cgiar.org)

Dear Christian,

I am sharing the revised version of narrative and budget for RwaSIS. We are providing our opinions with regards to a number of issues that you have raised (see track changes). The following are some thoughts on the comments raised in your earlier email:

1- FAIR Data Principles: Regarding the issue of data open access policy, I plan a meeting with RISA, Rwanda Information Society Authority, mandated to oversee Government database storage, management and access. I wish to discuss with them on the opportunity to develop a data open access policy for Rwanda. 

2- Ex-Ante Analysis: The study would be most welcome but I think much of the information we are looking for are already available for Rwanda. My view is that we need simple and straightforward analytical tools to enable identifying priority areas, we already know the priority crops that we should focused on for Rwanda. 

3- Soil conservation: I agree with you on this. Much has been worked on with regards to soil conservation for Rwanda, at least on research side. I do believe  some broader consultation would be much needed to elaborate more on the potential solutions. RAB scientists have extensively worked on soil conservation, highlighting the potential of technologies (solutions) such as bench and progressive terraces, tree and shrubs etc...Other key partners would be the Ministry of Environment. 

4- Project lead: I agree that we need to nominate a project leader. I personally know Dr Alain Ndoli, he is now with IUCN and am not sure he would want to resign and join the project. I have attempted to call him for a discussion but he is currently out of the country. I will make a follow-up on this. However, I tend to favour hiring somebody with experience in AfSIS approach. Simply because this is a 2 years project with high expectation and that will require a project leader who will immediately take the lead and provide a strategic and clear implementation plan without further delays. On the other side, I would welcome an appointment of Rwandan staff (eventually from RAB) serving as assistant project leader to ensure transfer of knowledge and sustainability.

5- I fully support having ISRIC on board and I guess its contribution will be instrumental in equipping national staff with skills and knowledge in digital soil mapping.   

We have proposed changes in track changes for your approval in the narrative and have also made changes in the budget. However, the results framework seem to be protected so it is not possible to add additional rows and insert suggested new activities. May I request any support to enable us accessing files to help capturing those activities. 

Sincerely,

Charles

Dr. Charles BUCAGU

Deputy Director General in charge of Agricultural Research and Technology Transfer

Rwanda Agriculture Board (RAB) - Ministry of Agriculture and Animal Resources (MINAGRI)

Mobile: (+250)788305182

E-Mail:bucagucharles@gmail.com

Subject: ToR for Front End project
 
Hello,
 
Please find attached a draft of ToR document for the Government Web Presence Front end.
 
Highlights: 
 
The ToR propose to migrate (or add) content for gov.rw portal as well as for one institution of each of the site template eg. Embassy template, migrate content for only Rwanda Embassy in Israel etc, ministries for only MINICT for the purpose of testing the templates and collecting the information for migration plan and knowledge transfer. Assume the backend will not be ready yet, RISA team will create a temporary instance to be used for that purpose.
Training and support would serve to allow RISA team to be familiar with the “Front end” code, structure and features etc. so that they can take the lead and easily support even for migrating template and content to the permanent back end when completed.
 
Thoughts, suggestions, observations, questions?
 
Best Regards,
 
Leon

From: Juliette NYIRANEZA  
Sent: Wednesday, July 24, 2019 4:44 PM
To: typo3support@risa.gov.rw
Cc: lucie.uwizeye@risa.gov.rw
Subject: MINEDUC website 

 

Dear Typo3 Support Team , 

 

This email serves to request for your help in updating www.mineduc.gov.rw
 

 

I. STAFF CONTACT : 

- Kindly add  : Under MINISTER'S OFFICE  1. NTAGANDA James ,  Advisor to the
Minister of Education , Tel  0789806210 , Email: jntaganda@mineduc.gov.rw
  

2. Under SPIU : MUGISHA Fred  SPIU Procurement Specialist  Position
:procurement specialist 

Phone :0783055637

fmugisha@mineduc.gov.rw  

 

3. Under SPIU:  BAMWINE Gordon , Tel 0788 889 668 , TVET Sub Sector Working
Group Cordinator ,Email: gbamwine@mineduc.gov.rw
  

 

II. STATISTICS 

We have realised you picked the wrong document last time while putting the
web live. So kindly add the attached documents  ( Statistics Data Collection
Tools ) 

 

Give them the following names  : 

 

 1. DCT A 2019 Pre- Nursery

 

 2. DCT B 2019 Nursery

 

 3. DCT C 2019 Primary

 

 4. DCT D 2019 Gen Secondary

 

 5. DCT E 2019 TVET level 1 to 5

 

 6. DCT G 2019 TVET short courses

 

 7. DCT H 2018- 2019 Tertiary 

 

 8. DCT F 2019 Adult Literacy

 

 9. Summary 2019 List of all schools 

 

Thank you.

Juliette

 

 

............................................................................
............................................................................
............... 

Play your part in the Education Sector Strategic Plan (ESSP): The ESSP is
creating a better education for everyone in Rwanda, which means a brighter
future for all. The ESSP has three main objectives: to increase ACCESS to
education for all; to improve the QUALITY of education; and to strengthen
the RELEVANCE of education for the job market. Together, we have already
achieved a lot. Together, we can go much further, must faster. Find out more
about the ESSP at www.mineduc.gov.rw  . Or follow
us on Twitter at @Rwanda_Edu

rduhuze@rema.gov.rw; bcyiza@rema.gov.rw; angelique.dusabeyezu@rra.gov.rw;

Alain Murara 
Cc: Alfred Byiringiro ; Francois Zirikana
; DIV.TRANSPORT
; Yoji Sakakibara ;
Laurent NDIZIHIWE ; Theogene
DUSABUMUREMYI 
Subject: Invitation to the presentation of the first Interim Report on
Vehicle Inspection Restructuring Study

 

Dear All,

Good afternoon,

Reference is made to the cabinet resolution of 11th July 2018 requesting the
Ministry of Infrastructure to speed up the process of restructuring motor
vehicle inspection system in order to cope with the increment of motorized
fleet;

Reference is made to the Memorandum of Understanding between MININFRA and
Toyota Mobility Foundation governing the carrying out of the Vehicle
Inspection Restructuring study; 

Reference is also made to the letters addressed to your respective
institutions requesting focal persons for this study.

I hereby invite you in the meeting to discuss the findings of the study
presented in the first Interim report.

The meeting will take place in Hotel des Milles collines on 31st July 2019
at 8:30 am. 

Kindly find attached the Agenda for the meeting and other working document.

 

 

Thank you and best regards

............

Janvier TWAGIRIMANA

Transport External Link & Donor Coordinator

Cell: +250788301015

Subject: Re: Request for support on TYPO3 website 

Dear Theobard, 
Your request is well received. 
We shall get back to you once done. 

Regards, 


From: "Theobard Bayingana"  
To: "elisabeth ujeneza"  
Sent: Tuesday, July 30, 2019 7:59:26 AM 
Subject: Request for support on TYPO3 website 



Dear Elisabeth, 



Hope you are doing well. 



I would like to request for your software support team to help us in adding Rwanda Forensic Laboratory (RFL) flicker link : [ https://www.flickr.com/photos/182836930@N03/ | https://www.flickr.com/photos/182836930@N03/ ] on [ http://www.rfl.gov.rw/ | www.rfl.gov.rw ] website and change the existing rfl Instagram link: from [ https://www.instagram.com/rwanda.forensics/ | https://www.instagram.com/rwanda.forensics/ ] to [ https://www.instagram.com/rwandaforensiclaboratory.rfl/ | https://www.instagram.com/rwandaforensiclaboratory.rfl/ ] . 



Thank you . 

Regards, 



BAYINGANA Theobard 

IT Specialist 

Rwanda Forensic Laboratory 

Phone: +250788688466 / +250737555779 

Email: theobard.bayingana@rfl.gov.rw

From: Donatien Uhoraningoga  
Sent: Tuesday, July 30, 2019 4:56 PM
To: typo3support@risa.gov.rw
Subject: FW: Documents to be uploaded on MINEDUC Website (ESMF&RPF)

 

 

 

From: Charles Ntawigira [mailto:cntawigira2@gmail.com] 
Sent: Tuesday, July 30, 2019 1:48 PM
To: donatien.uhoraningoga@risa.gov.rw  
Cc: juliettenyiraneza@gmail.com  ; Wilson Rurangwa  >; Odile MUHAYIMANA  >
Subject: Documents to be uploaded on MINEDUC Website (ESMF&RPF)

 

Dear Donatien,

 

Please find herewith attached the documents to be uploaded in replacement of the documents which have been uploaded on MINEDUC Website, under Projects-Quality Basic Education for Human Capital Development Project.

 

Please note that the documents to be replaced are two while other two will remain.

The documents to be removed and replaced by the documents of the same name are:- Environmental and Social Management Framework (ESMF) 

               -Resettlement Policy Framework (RPF)

 

We will be very grateful if this can be treated as a matter of urgency and please send us the link after uploading the documents.

 

For any needed further clarification, please don't hesitate to reach out to me.

 

Regards;

Charles 

Tel:0783146509

Dear Alain

Can you please see schedule a meeting with Ernest.

Regards
—————————————
Said Rutabayiro Ngoga, PhD
Division Manager Technology Innovation
Rwanda Information Society Authority (RISA)
saidngoga.rutabayiro@risa.gov.rw
said.rutabayiro.ngoga@gmail.com
+250 783 111 906

Begin forwarded message:

From: "Mudenge Ernest Kwizera"
Subject: Re: Automation in irrigation
Date: July 31, 2019 at 07:16:36 GMT+2
To: "Emile Ruzibiza" , saidngoga.rutabayiro@risa.gov.rw, leon.muvunyi@giz.de
Reply-To: "Mudenge Ernest Kwizera"

Hi Mr. Leon & Mr.Ngoga,

Mr. Emile urakoze kuduhuza na Ngoga & Leon kadni bikaba ari intambwe nziza yo kugirango dushyigikire ubuhinzi bwacu murwanda dukoresheje Modernized technologies.

Mr. Leon & Mr.Ngoga, Nkuko Mr. Emile yari amaze kubivuga Nitwa MUDENGE Ernest KWIZERA nkaba mpagarariye MMOTTECH WATER MANAGEMENT PLC, it is a an Israel company with an African HQ in South Africa of which i am its representative here in Rwanda, Burundi and DR Congo.

We are now connecting with you Mr. Leon & Mr.Ngoga, in order to resquest appointments so that we can present to you what we do and how we can work together in the coming days.

Attached are our service intervention brochures brochures both in Agriculture and Water supply.

Looking forward to hear from you soon.

Regards,

------ Original Message ------
From: "Emile Ruzibiza" >
To: saidngoga.rutabayiro@risa.gov.rw ; leon.muvunyi@giz.de
Cc: ernest.kwizera@mottech.co.za
Sent: 7/30/2019 10:55:12 AM
Subject: Automation in irrigation

Hi Ngoga and Leon. Nababuze kuri tel.
Hari umuntu ufite service za automation muri irrigation. Yaje kutureba adusaba ko twa mulinkinga n`aba potential partners bacu bashobora kuba bakeneye izo services. Ari also copied on this email. Yitwa Mudenge Ernest Kwizera.

So, iyi email nukugirango mbahuze murebe niba hari icyo mwakwungurana muri iyi journey ya Innovation.

Thanking you

Emile

This email has been checked for viruses by Avast antivirus software.
www.avast.com

From: amunezero@minict.gov.rw [mailto:amunezero@minict.gov.rw] 
Sent: Wednesday, July 31, 2019 5:30 PM
To: 'Ben Rwamucyo' 
Subject: FW: THALES MEETING

 

 

FYI

 

 



 

From: Francis Rugema [mailto:frugema@rac.co.rw] 
Sent: Wednesday, July 31, 2019 17:25
To: Blaise Jabo  >; Marshal Gasana
 >; Janvier Mugisha
 >; Norbert Niyonizera
 >; Dan Karake
 >; Michael Shyaka
 >; Aloys Mupenzi
 >; Emmanuel Sabiiti
 >; Sylvestre Manirambona
 >;
amunezero@minict.gov.rw  
Cc: Isabelle Umugwaneza  >
Subject: THALES MEETING

 

Hello,

 

We will be having the Thales session tomorrow at Grand Legacy Hotel from
9AM. Agenda is the one shared by Thales reps earlier.

 

*  Regulatory Environment (Global and Local)

*  Concept of ATM (Identification of main stakeholders)

*  Thales ECOsystem UTM architecture (Soarizon part is addressed here)

*  Thales solution Status,

*  Airspace design R&D,

*  Thales Case Studies & Experiences

*  UAS trends (global and local)

*  POC discussion ( framing and timeline )

Kind Regards,

 

Francis

From: Mustafa Sibomana  
Sent: Monday, August 5, 2019 2:13 PM
To: Felicite Amahoro 
Cc: Yasmin D. Amri-sued ; lucie uwizeye ; Grace ; Etiennentihemuka Birara ; Elisabeth Ujeneza ; Vincent DUHIMBAZE 
Subject: Re: Websites for Abu Dhabi and Dubai

 

Dear Lucie 

 

I think we can install anydesk and do a conf call so you will be able to see what we are talking about, let us know your availability  it will be helpful if we close this by thursday, 30 min will be enough.

 

Regards

Mustapha

 

Sent from my iPhone


On Jun 27, 2019, at 10:25 PM, Felicite Amahoro  > wrote:

Dear Amri,

 

It is well noted.

 

Thanks

 

 

 

 

AMAHORO Felicite

Ag. ICT Director

Ministry of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation 

Email :   famahoro@minaffet.gov.rw

Skype: famahoro

Whatsapp: +82-10-46478892

Tel: +250 788598825



 

From: Yasmin D. Amri-sued 
Sent: jeudi 27 juin 2019 20:00
To: Felicite Amahoro  >
Cc: lucie uwizeye  >; Grace  >; Mustafa Sibomana  >; Etiennentihemuka Birara  >; Elisabeth Ujeneza  >; Vincent DUHIMBAZE  >
Subject: Re: Websites for Abu Dhabi and Dubai

 

Dear Félicité,

 

Let’s have the meeting on the 18th July @ 10:00 Kgl time.

 

I will share link few days prior that we can use.

 

Best Regards

 

Yasmin 


On Jun 27, 2019, at 9:23 PM, Felicite Amahoro  > wrote:

Dear Amri,

 

Hope you are doing well.

 

This email serves as follow-up on below correspondences, do you have any other alternative solutions ?

 

Thanks

 

 

 

AMAHORO Felicite

Ag. ICT Director

Ministry of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation 

Email :   famahoro@minaffet.gov.rw

Skype: famahoro

Whatsapp: +82-10-46478892

Tel: +250 788598825



 

From: Felicite Amahoro 
Sent: mardi 25 juin 2019 22:37
To: lucie uwizeye  >
Cc: Yasmin D. Amri-sued  >; Grace  >; Mustafa Sibomana  >; Etiennentihemuka Birara  >; Elisabeth Ujeneza  >; Vincent DUHIMBAZE  >
Subject: RE: Websites for Abu Dhabi and Dubai

 

Dear Lucie,

 

I do understand. 

They will let us know how you can get in touch.

 

Thanks

 

 

 

Sent from my Samsung Galaxy smartphone.

 

 

-------- Original message --------

From: lucie uwizeye  > 

Date: 6/25/2019 4:37 PM (GMT+02:00) 

To: Felicite Amahoro  > 

Cc: "Yasmin D. Amri-sued"  >, Grace  >, Mustafa Sibomana  >, Etiennentihemuka Birara  >, Elisabeth Ujeneza  >, Vincent DUHIMBAZE  > 

Subject: Re: Websites for Abu Dhabi and Dubai 

 

Dear Felicite,

 

We are sorry we didn't, due to network connectivity on our side, we tried to use Skype call but the staff in Abu Dhabi told us that it can't work in the UAE, for us we do not have another option unless they give us the link where we can connect to them.

 

Regards,

 


  _____

description.raw:
Dear Kigali PRT Technical Committee:
 
This email is to confirm the primary decisions made at today’s meeting. Please let me know of any omissions or corrections you would like to point out.
 
Attendees:
Janvier Twagirimana, MININFRA
Innocent Bajiji RDB
Alain Murara, RURA
Rodrique Ruhashya, MINICT
Said Ngoga RISA
Peter Muller, VUBA
 
The purpose of the meeting was to agree on the Terms of Reference (ToR) for the Kigali PRT Feasibility Study with the goal of establishing a reasonable price and schedule. The draft ToR was previously circulated and is also attached hereto. The PowerPoint Presentation used in the meeting can be downloaded here: https://www.dropbox.com/s/263khqmefi54heu/20190616%20Vuba%20Feasibility%20ToR.pptx?dl=0 
 
The Draft ToR was found acceptable with the following points of emphasis/changes:
 
TASK THREE  DEVELOP AN INTEGRATED TRANSPORT PLAN (ITP)
The focus will be on the PRT service area of about 65 square kilometres. Planning beyond this area will be at a high level only. Infrastructure for modes other than PRT will be assumed to be as existing or as included in existing plans. Maximum use will be made of data, plans, mode splits, etc. obtained for/provided by existing studies.
 
The study shall examine impacts on existing and planned modes. In particular it will investigate the natural mode switch to PRT including the possible need to restrict the use of motos within the PRT service area and the need to initially charge more than bus fare for Economy tickets to transition the mode switch from bus to PRT over a suitable period of time. 
 
The possible restriction of Economy fares to people of social division 1 and/or 2 was discussed and favorably considered. This could help allow high quality service being provided to present bus riders without jeopardizing the system’s economic viability (present moto users switching to Economy PRT rather than Premium or Standard PRT fares could be problematic).
 
Consider only two supply-side scenarios:
PRT plus motos, buses and BRT
PRT
 
If there is a need to consider PRT plus buses, use the results of the BRT study and assume the results for motos apply to PRT.
 
The feasibility study will determine the smallest deployment that can be financially viable. This will comprise Phase I of the project which it is anticipated will be immediately followed by deployment of Phase II to complete the 66 square kilometre deployment. If a pilot deployment smaller than Phase I is required, it will not be financially viable. This means that funding will need to be provided to cover any required pause in development from the pilot to Phase I.
 
TASK TWELVE  ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND GENDER IMPACT ASSESSMENT
It needs to be determined by RDB whether the environmental task requires a full ESIA to Rwanda and IFC standards or just an environmental screening.
 
GENERAL
The Ministry of Environment and the City of Kigali were not represented in the meeting. Meetings with representatives of these entities will be arranged for Mr. Muller before his departure on midday Thursday June 20. A meeting with RDB to discuss  environmental requirements will also be arranged.
 
The ToR will be revised according to the decisions made in the meeting and input from the follow-up meetings. It will be submitted along with a detailed cost breakdown within a month.
 
 
Best regards,
 
Peter Muller
 
 		
Peter Muller Chief Technology Officer
m |
+1 720 318 4795  
e |
peter@go-vuba.com 
a |
1440 Newport Rd, Col Springs, CO 80916, USA

—————————————
Said Rutabayiro Ngoga, PhD
Division Manager Technology Innovation
Rwanda Information Society Authority (RISA)
saidngoga.rutabayiro@risa.gov.rw
said.rutabayiro.ngoga@gmail.com
+250 783 111 906



> Begin forwarded message:
> 
> From: "Peter Muller" 
> Subject: Revised PRT Feasibility Study ToR, Schedule and Budget
> Date: July 29, 2019 at 17:35:35 GMT+2
> To: "Alain Murara" , "Gordon Kale" , "Innocent Bajiji" , , "Rodrique Ruhashya" , "Said Ngoga" , "William Mugabo" 
> Cc: "'Paul Klahn'" 
>

Said Ngoga RISA
Peter Muller, VUBA

The purpose of the meeting was to agree on the Terms of Reference (ToR) for the Kigali PRT Feasibility Study with the goal of establishing a reasonable price and schedule. The draft ToR was previously circulated and is also attached hereto. The PowerPoint Presentation used in the meeting can be downloaded here: https://www.dropbox.com/s/263khqmefi54heu/20190616%20Vuba%20Feasibility%20ToR.pptx?dl=0

The Draft ToR was found acceptable with the following points of emphasis/changes:

TASK THREE DEVELOP AN INTEGRATED TRANSPORT PLAN (ITP)
The focus will be on the PRT service area of about 65 square kilometres. Planning beyond this area will be at a high level only. Infrastructure for modes other than PRT will be assumed to be as existing or as included in existing plans. Maximum use will be made of data, plans, mode splits, etc. obtained for/provided by existing studies.

The study shall examine impacts on existing and planned modes. In particular it will investigate the natural mode switch to PRT including the possible need to restrict the use of motos within the PRT service area and the need to initially charge more than bus fare for Economy tickets to transition the mode switch from bus to PRT over a suitable period of time.

The possible restriction of Economy fares to people of social division 1 and/or 2 was discussed and favorably considered. This could help allow high quality service being provided to present bus riders without jeopardizing the system’s economic viability (present moto users switching to Economy PRT rather than Premium or Standard PRT fares could be problematic).

Consider only two supply-side scenarios:
PRT plus motos, buses and BRT
PRT

If there is a need to consider PRT plus buses, use the results of the BRT study and assume the results for motos apply to PRT.

The feasibility study will determine the smallest deployment that can be financially viable. This will comprise Phase I of the project which it is anticipated will be immediately followed by deployment of Phase II to complete the 66 square kilometre deployment. If a pilot deployment smaller than Phase I is required, it will not be financially viable. This means that funding will need to be provided to cover any required pause in development from the pilot to Phase I.

TASK TWELVE ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND GENDER IMPACT ASSESSMENT
It needs to be determined by RDB whether the environmental task requires a full ESIA to Rwanda and IFC standards or just an environmental screening.

GENERAL
The Ministry of Environment and the City of Kigali were not represented in the meeting. Meetings with representatives of these entities will be arranged for Mr. Muller before his departure on midday Thursday June 20. A meeting with RDB to discuss environmental requirements will also be arranged.

The ToR will be revised according to the decisions made in the meeting and input from the follow-up meetings. It will be submitted along with a detailed cost breakdown within a month.

Best regards,

Peter Muller

Peter Muller Chief Technology Officer

+1 720 318 4795

a |
1440 Newport Rd, Col Springs, CO 80916, USA

Dear Aparupa,

Many thanks for the email below and for shedding light on the sectors in which the delegation from Mitsui is looking to explore while in Rwanda.

As we aim to put together a draft program, would like to request you to share the list of delegates and their profiles………
